messageBody:
>-----Original Message-----
>From: Steven Taschuk [mailto:staschuk@...]
>Sent: Thursday, September 12, 2002 2:32 PM
>To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: Re: RE: [junit] [TEST] JTest v4.5 and what is says about JUnit
>
>
>Quoth Chappell, Simon P:
>> >-----Original Message-----
>> >From: Steven Taschuk [mailto:staschuk@...]
>[...]
>> >But why would the calling code care? For example, why would it
>> >react differently to an IllegalArgExc than to any random
>> >RuntimeException?
>>
>> Good question. I hope that I can provide a good answer. The reason
>> why my code would care about the type of exception raised by the
>> code that I have called is that there are some exceptions that are
>> non-terminal and that when received, my code will try to do
>> something about it. Let's try an example:
>[...snip examples...]
>
>Yes, certainly. I understand your example of JDBC exceptions, for
>which the strategy of retrying a few times may be appropriate.
>
>But what error-recovery strategy, if any, is appropriate for
>IllegalArgExc but inappropriate for other RuntimeExcs? In other
>words:
> try {
> // Some code.
> } catch (IllegalArgumentException e) {
> // What might be done here ...
> } catch (RuntimeException e) {
> // ... that wouldn't be equally sensible here?
> }
>

There is no error recovery strategy, but the reporting is going to be different.

I think that, for me, it's partly a matter of "rightness" and the rest is reporting. The "rightness" is that it is the Right Thing To Do(tm) to throw a IAE when receiving junk parameters. In your code fragment, the different things that I might do would be to issue different errors to the user or log file. An IAE means that the programmer goofed, while other errors might be for less negligent reasons.

For example, if my code is reading a file from a CD and someone ejects the CD during the process then I expect an error to be thrown, but it's not the fault of the programmer, so let's put up a nice friendly end-user message that explains how difficult it is to read data from a CD that isn't in the drive anymore.

As I type this response, I realise that my whole programming perspective is driving my answer. That is, that I very deliberately write what I call "2 a.m. code". This is code that someone else can debug at 2 a.m. without talking to me. I write VERY BORING and VERY STRAIGHTFORWARD code and I do it deliberately. I find two advantages to this: the first is that other people can support the code more easily and the second is that boring, straightforward code breaks less often (my perception, no scientific proof).

I gained this worldview from trying to support other people's RPG code. There was one particular job that ran at 2 a.m. on Friday night/Saturday morning and by the time it failed and the operators paged me it would be 2:15 (almost exactly ... everytime). The code was awful and that was when I started trying to write code (and encourage others to also write their code that way) that any support programmer could read and understand and patch if necessary at 2 a.m.

I hope this explains why I'm being so rigid about this. If I pass a junk value as a parameter then I want an IllegalArgumentException. Don't give me a NullPointerException ... that tells me nothing at 2 a.m.!!! You can give me all the theory that you want about how an NPE is fine if it's documented in the JavaDoc or some Big Book Of Documentation, but once you've supported some idiot's spagetti code at 2 a.m. (without the BBOD to hand), then theory doesn't appeal like it used to.

More than two cents, but less than a dollar. :-)

Simon
